Title: Esri Canada Health GIS Hub
Author: Esri Canada
Abstract:
ArcGIS Hub site curated with Canadian health related data, web mapping applications, use cases, and links to external resources.

Data categories include: healthcare service locations, health administrative boundaries, COVID-19 data, and health data sites such as Health Canada and the Canadian Institute for Health Information (CIHI).

The Health GIS Hub also includes web mapping applications on topics such as air quality, smoke forecasts, radon, west nile, and more.

Other resources include links to the Learn ArcGIS site for healthcare related tutorials.

Title: PurpleAir
Author: Purple Air, Inc.
Abstract: PurpleAir makes sensors that empower Community Scientists who collect hyper-local air quality data and share it with the public. PurpleAir is built on the ideals of sharing data and empowering individuals to institute real change. Air quality data is accessible hyper-locally in real-time via numerous sensors including the PurpleAir Touch Indoor Air Quality Monitor and the PurpleAir Zen Air Quality Monitor. These industry-leading sensors measure particle pollution (PM2.5) and are priced at a fraction of what you pay for a commercial sensor. Their indoor and outdoor air quality sensors are easy to install and connect seamlessly to your WIFI network.
Metadata: More information on PurpleAir's metadata and privacy information can be found at the following link: https://www2.purpleair.com/policies/privacy-policy
How to Cite This: Format: Author. Map title. Date produced and time if known. Scale or resolution. “Title of complete document or site”. <URL>

Title: Territorial Evolution
Author: University of Toronto
Format: Shapefiles (.shp), arcmap documents, and supporting documents, including data tables, legends, and snapshots of the maps displayed on the website.
Abstract:
Borealis, the Canadian Dataverse Repository, is a bilingual, multidisciplinary, secure, Canada research data repository, supported by academic libraries and research instituations across Canada. Borealis supports open discovery, management, sharing, and preservation of Canadian research data.

This dataset contains all data for the maps "Boundary Changes, 1670-2001" and "Newfoundland Joins Confederation, 1949" from Unit 17: territorial Evolution, 1670-2001 in the Historical Atlas of Canada Online Learning Project.
Metadata: Metadata infomation can be found at the following link under the "Metadata" tab: https://borealisdata.ca/dataset.xhtml?persistentId=doi:10.5683/SP2/IQ7E0X

Title: Natural Earth
Author:
Many volunteer NACIS members and cartographers around the globe outlined below:
https://www.naturalearthdata.com/about/contributors/
Abstract:
Natural Earth is a public domain map dataset available at 1:10m, 1:50m, and 1:110 million scales. Featuring tightly integrated vector and raster data. with Natural Earth you can make a variety of visually pleasing, well-crafted maps with cartography or GIS software.

Natural Earth solves a problem: finding suitable data for making small-scale maps. In a time when the web is awash in geospatial data, cartographers are forced to waste time sifting through confusing tangles of poorly attributed data to make clean, legible maps. Because your time if valuable, Natural Earth data comes ready-to-use.
Metadata: Every dataset has an accompanying comprehensive metadata document provided in PDF format with the downloaded dataset.
How to Cite This: Format: Author. Title. Edition. Scale. Place of publication: Publisher, Date.

Title: Canada Elevation Data
Author: ESRI Canada
Format: GeoTIFF files with acociated PDF and Extensible Markup Language (.xml) files.
Abstract: Canadian Elevation Data is a public Canadian resource available through the geospatial product index which allows the user to select their desired data type and collection from prepackaged datasets, then freely download the dataset for public use. The optional datasets include imagery, raster, vector, and elevation. From here, the user has the option to choose from multiple topographic collections which map across Canada.
Metadata: Every dataset has an accompanying comprehensive metadata document provided in PDF format with the downloaded dataset.
How to Cite This: Format: Author. Title. Edition. Scale. Place of publication: Publisher, Date.

Title: Historic Bathymetry Maps
Author: Ontario Ministry of Na
Abstract:
The historic bathymetry maps were created using simple methods to determine lake depths and were meant for resource management purposes only.

Bathymetry is the measurement of water depth in lakes. From the 1940s to the 1990s, the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry produced bathymetry maps for over 11,000 lakes across Ontario.

The data can be used by the general public and GIS specialists for:

  • climate chnage modelling
  • fish monitoring and other ecological applications
  • hydrologic cycle modelling
  • recreational fishing maps
  • watershed-based water budgeting

The maps were created using simple methods to determine lake depths. They were meant for resource anagement purposes only. Little effort was made to identify shoal and other hazads when creating these bathymetric maps.

Since this data was collected, many constructed and naturally occuring events could mean that the depth information is now inaccurate, so these maps should not be used for navigational purposes. In many cases, these maps still represent the only authoritative source of bathymetry data for lakes in Ontario.
Metadata: A detailed outline of the Ontario Historic Bathymetry Maps metadata can be found at the following link: https://www.arcgis.com/sharing/rest/content/items/19b6e1fbfba846cd80a11acda6b9e1d4/info/metadata/metadata.xml?format=default&output=html
How to Cite This: Format: Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry. Ontario Historic Bathymetry Maps. 2014 Ed. [scale]. Peterborough, ON: Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry, 2023.

Title: USGS National Hydrology Datasets
Author: ESRI
Format: PNG32, PNG24, PNG, JPG, DIB, TIFF, EMF, PS, PDF, GIF, SVG, SVGZ, or BMP files.
Abstract:
The USGS National Hydrography Dataset (NHD) service from The National Map is a comprehensive set of digital spatial data that encodes information about naturally occurring and constructed bodies of surface water (lakes, ponds, and reservoirs), paths through which water. flows (canals, ditches, streams, and rivers), and related entities such as point features (springs, wells, stream gages, and dams.

The National Map download client allows free downloads of public domain NHD data in either Esri File Geodatabase or Shapefile formats.
Metadata: Metadata can be found at the following link under "Document Info:" https://hydro.nationalmap.gov/arcgis/rest/services/nhd/MapServer
How to Cite This: Format: Author. Title. Edition. Scale. Place of publication: Publisher, Date.

Title: National Hydrology Network
Abstract:
The Notional Hydrographic networks are datasets containing representations of surface water features. These features can include lakes, reservoirs, rivers, streams, islands, obstacles (e.g., waterfalls) and constructions (e.g., dams, wharves, dikes).

With national coverage, this is our most complete network. It is available to be used in many applications such as cartographic display, hydraulic analysis, or as base data. The network was started in 2004 with many federal, provincial and territorial partners. It has not been maintained since 2022 but remains a popular dataset.
Metadata: Every dataset has an accompanying comprehensive metadata document provided in PDF format with the downloaded dataset.
How to Cite This:
Format:
USGS The National Map.  National Hydography Dataset.  [Edition].  [Scale] (1:24000-100000).  [Place of Publication]: USGS, 2024.

Title: SOLRIS 3.0
Author: Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources
Format: GeoDatabase (.gdb), Portable Document Format (PDF), Tagged Image File Format (TIFF), and Layer File (.lyr).
Abstract:
SOLRIS is a primary data layer that provides a comprehensive, standardized, landscape level inventory of natural, rural and urbanlands in Ecoregions 7E, 6E, and 5E.

SOLRIS is based on MNRF's Ecological Land Classification (ELC) for southern Ontario (Lee at al, 1998). It is a land use inventory that supports a number of key provincial initiatives including: State of Natural Resources Reporting (Forestry, Biodiversity), Natural Heritage Features Reporting (wetlands, woodlands), Climate Chnage Reporting and Land Use Planning. Maintained on a consistent update dycle, SOLRIS provides a standardized geospatial information layer that allows for reporting on changes in natural and anthropogenic features, such as wetland extent, forest afforestation/deforestation, habitat connectivity and built-up areas (impervious/pervious).
Metadata: A detailed outline of the SOLRIS 3.0 metadata can be found at the following link: https://www.arcgis.com/sharing/rest/content/items/0279f65b82314121b5b5ec93d76bc6ba/info/metadata/metadata.xml?format=default&output=html
How to Cite This:
Format:
Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry.  SOLRIS 3.0.  [Scale].  Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario: King's Printer for Ontario, 2023.

Title: Ontario Land Cover Compilation v2.0
Author: Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry
Abstract:
The Ontario Land Cover Compilation (OLCC) is a rationalized land cover product for the province, combining 3 separate land cover databases.

The 3 combined land cover databases:

  1. Far North Land Cover v1.4
  2. Southern Ontario Land Resource Information SYstem (SOLRIS) v1.2
  3. the Provincial Land Cover 2000 Edition
Metadata: A detailed outline of the Ontario Land Cover Compilation v2.0 metadata can be found at the following link: https://www.arcgis.com/sharing/rest/content/items/7aa998fdf100434da27a41f1c637382c/info/metadata/metadata.xml?format=default&output=html
How to Cite This:
Format:
Ontario Land Cover Compilation v.2.0. 15m.  Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario: King's Printer for Ontario, 2023.

Title: 2020 Land Cover of Canada
Author: CCRS, CCMEO, NRCAN
Format: Tagged Image File Format (TIFF), Extensible Markup Language (.xml), and Portable Document Format (PDF).
Abstract:
Land cover information is necessary for a large range on environmental applications related to climate impacts and adaption, emergency responce, wildlife habitat, etc. In Canada, a 2008 user survey indicated that the most practical land cover data is provided in a nationwide 30m spatial resolution format, with an update frequency of five years. In response to the need, the Canada Centre for Remote Sensing (CCRS) has generated a 30m land cover map of Canada for the years 2010, 2025 as well as this 2020 land cover map.

This land cover dataset is also the Canadian contribution to the 30m spatial resolution 2020 Land Cover Map of North America, which is produced by Mexican, American and Canadian government institutions under a collaboration called the North American Land Change Monitoring System (NALCMS).

This land cover dataset for Canada is produced using observation from Operational Land Imaer (OLI) Landsat sensor. An accuracy assessment based on 832 randomly distributed samples shows that landcover data produced with this new approach has achieved 86.9% accuracy with no marked spatial disparities.
How to Cite This:
Data Producer. Name of database or source. Title of map, image or table. Person who generated map or table; Software package used to generate map or table; . (Date map or table was generated).

Citation Infomation can be found at the link under "Additional Information."

Title: North American Rail Lines
Author: US Department of Transportation
Abstract:
North American Rail Network (NARN) can be used within the public, the federal govenment, rail industry, state DOTs, and academia for routing, mapping and analysis.

The North American Rail Network Rail Lines dataset was created in 2016 and was updated on October 16, 2024 from the Federal Railroad Administration (FRA) and is part of the U.S. Department of Transportation (USDOT)/Bureau of Transportation Statistics (BTS) National Transportation Atlas Database (NTAD). The NARN Rail Lines dataset is a database that provides ownership, trackage rights, type, passenger, STRACNET, and geographic reference for North America's railway system at 1:24000 or better within the United States. The data set covers all 50 States, the District of Columbia, Mexico, and Canada.
Metadata: A detailed outline of the North American Rail Lines Metadata can be found at the following link: https://www.arcgis.com/sharing/rest/content/items/e143f436d4774402aa8cca1e663b1d24/info/metadata/metadata.xml?format=default&output=html
How to Cite This: Format: North American Rail Network Lines. National Transportation Atlas Database. 2016 Ed. 1:24000. Washington, DC. Federal Railroad Administration, 2024.

Title: US Traffic Volume Data
Author: Federal Railroad Administration
Abstract:
State highway agencies collect traffic volume data through both temporary traffic counting and continuous traffic counting programs and report their continuous counting data to FHWA on a monthly basis. Data listed here are reported by states following data format prescribed in FHWA's 2001 Traffic Monitoring Guide located at https://www.fhwa.dot.gov/policyinformation/tmguide/. Starting with the 2020 datasets, the traffic monitoring data released is piped delimited, quality reviewed and used in the Traffic Volume Trends (TVT) process with the same field names as contained in the 2001 TMG (the original data [prior to 2020] with the rigid fixed column format).

To provide an improved data user experience, the FHWA has developed a data tool to convert the current 24 hourly traffic data columns into two columns: Hour_Record and Hour_Volume. In addition, the tool parsed the original data with the comma symbol along with the needed data header. Please review the tool document on how to use it.
How to Cite This: Format: Author. Title. Edition. Scale. Place of publication: Publisher, Date.

Title: Traffic Volume by Census Tract
Author: Various
Abstract: This dataset contains measures of traffic volume per census tract in the United States from 1963 to 2019 (primarily 1997 to 2019). High traffic volume may be used as a proxy for heavy traffic, high traffic speeds, and impediments to walking or biking. The dataset contains measures of the average, maximum, and minimum traffic volume per tract per year. These figures are available for all streets, highways, and non-highways.
Metadata: Downloadable metadata can be found at the following link under "Export Metadata:" https://www.openicpsr.org/openicpsr/project/160262/version/V1/view;jsessionid=7A1D4CADDB111D42E72028FAAB92B4F1
How to Cite This: Finlay, Jessica, Melendez, Robert, Esposito, Michael, Khan, Anam, Li, Mao, Gomez-Lopez, Iris, … Chenoweth, Megan. National Neighborhood Data Archive (NaNDA): Traffic Volume by Census Tract, United States, 1963-2019. Ann Arbor, MI: Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research [distributor], 2022-01-20. https://doi.org/10.3886/E160262V1

Title: OpenStreetMap - Geofabrik Download Server
Author: Various
Abstract: OpenStreetMap is a map of the world, created by people like you and free to use under an open licence. OpenStreetMap is build by a community of mappers that contribute and maintain data about roads, trails, cafes, railway stations, and much more, all over the world. This server has data extracts fom thr OpenStreetMap project which are normally updated every day. Select your continent and then your country of interest.
Metadata: Extracts with full metadata are available to OpenStreetMap contributors only.
How to Cite This: Detailed information on how to credit OpenStreetMap can be found at the following link: https://www.openstreetmap.org/copyright

Title: QuickBird Satellite Imagery - Source Water Protection: Panchromatic imagery, greyscale
Author: Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources
Who Can Use This Data: McMaster Students / Staff / Faculty only. Login required for off-campus access.
Abstract:
The Source Water Protection QuickBird Imagery Project constitutes a high-resolution satellite imagery data set for approximately 120,000 km2 in the Province of Ontario. This data consists of orthorectified image derivatives from the Level Basic-1B bundled imagery provided to the Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources (OMNR) by Digital Globe, Inc.

Pansharpened images (60 - 70 cm true colour composites) are required for mapping applications that require high-resolution background imagery. Additional image derivatives, such as enhanced Multispectral and Greyscale (Panchromatic) products (GeoTIFF and MrSID formats) may also be generated depending on requirements. Raw (Basic-1B) imagery was secured from Digital Globe to ensure that the orthorectification process could be conducted under the supervision of OMNR staff, with an adherence to the geospatial standards of the Natural Resources Values Information System (NRVIS).
How to Cite This: Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources. QuickBird Satellite Imagery - Source Water Protection: Panchromatic imagery, greyscale [digital resource: grid]. Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources, (insert date). Retrieved from http://geo.scholarsportal.info/#r/details/_uri@=743637406.

Title: DMTI CanMaps Content and Postal Content Suite 2024 - full series
Author: DMTI Spatial Inc.
Who Can Use This Data: McMaster Students / Staff / Faculty only. Login required for off-campus access.
Abstract:
--------------------------------------------------------------------

Important Notice

The DMTI CMCS and CMPCS 2024.3 datasets are only available by request from students, staff, and faculty of subscribing institutions. Please email geoportal@scholarsportal.info to request access to the latest data.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

The DMTI CanMap Content Suite (CMCS) and CanMap Postal Content Suite (CMPCS) 2024.3 is a comprehensive geospatial dataset designed to support a wide range of applications in geographic information systems (GIS). This dataset includes over 300 layers of detailed mapping information, making it a valuable resource for urban planning, infrastructure management, environmental monitoring, and emergency response.

The current version of the CMCS and the CMPCS include updates to road networks, address points, and postal code boundaries, reflecting new developments and changes in infrastructure.

Key components:

  • CanMap Streetfiles: Detailed street-level data, including road networks, transportation routes, and address ranges. Useful in navigation, route optimization, and logistics planning.
  • Postal Code Suite OM: Postal code information, including six-digit postal code boundaries, delivery mode types, and point of call (POC) data. Useful for precise location-based analysis.
  • Address Points: Geocoded address information.
  • Natural Features Data: Includes information on rivers, lakes, parks, and other natural landmarks. Useful in environmental studies and land use planning.
  • Emergency Services Locations: Data includes the locations of hospitals, fire stations, police stations, and other critical services.
  • Political and Census Boundaries: Provides detailed information on electoral districts, municipal boundaries, and census divisions. Supports demographic analysis and policy development.

The following postal code data (down to the neighborhood level) is included in this dataset as part of the DMTI CMPCS collection:

  • Urban and Rural Six-Digit (FSA LDU) Boundaries: Precise delineation of postal code areas.
  • Full Point of Call (POC) Information: Includes detailed delivery mode types, such as residential, business, and community mailboxes.
  • Forward Sortation Areas (FSAs): Larger postal code areas useful for regional analysis.
How to Cite This: DMTI Spatial Inc. DMTI CanMaps Content and Postal Content Suite 2024 - full series [digital resource: vector]. DMTI Spatial Inc., 2024. Retrieved from http://geo.scholarsportal.info/#r/details/_uri@=3152044734.

Title: South Central Ontario Orthophotography Project (SCOOP) 2023 - Imagery
Author: Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources
Who Can Use This Data: McMaster Students / Staff / Faculty only. Login required for off-campus access.
Abstract:
Important Notice

The SCOOP 2023 data are only available by request to geoportal@scholarsportal.info. Please click on the blue 'Download' button to obtain a PDF that contains the details on how to request data and instructions on how to obtain it.

The South Central Ontario Orthophotography 2023 (SCOOP 2023) is an aerially acquired imagery data set covering approximately 43,692 square kilometres including parts of South Central Ontario, Toronto & the GTA, Peterborough, Haliburton, Muskoka, Simcoe, and surrounding areas.

This product is 4 band RGBN orthophotography at 8-bit depth, with a pixel resolution of 16 cm and it is accurate to 50 cm on the ground at the 95% confidence level.

The SCOOP 2023 was acquired by aerial photography using a Vexcel Ultracam digital camera in the spring of 2023, fall of 2023, and spring of 2024 under the best conditions possible to achieve cloud free, snow free, ice free, smoke free and leaf off/low leaf captures. The orthophotography has a pixel resolution of 16 centimetres and a stated accuracy of 50 centimetres on the ground. It was later orthorectified using an elevation dataset generated through image correlation.

The acquisition area spans two Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) Zones of UTM Zone 17 and UTM Zone 18. To view the acquisition area for each zone, visit the Ontario Geospatial Hub (see external documentation) or use the SCOOP 2023 1km Index files available here as zip downloads.
How to Cite This: Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources. South Central Ontario Orthophotography Project (SCOOP) 2023 - Imagery [digital resource: grid]. Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources, 2024. Retrieved from http://geo.scholarsportal.info/#r/details/_uri@=287212586.

Title: Digital Raster Acquisition Project Eastern Ontario (DRAPE) 2019
Author: Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources
Who Can Use This Data: McMaster Students / Staff / Faculty only. Login required for off-campus access.
Abstract:
Digital Raster Acquisition Project Eastern Ontario (DRAPE) was acquired in the spring of 2019/2020 under the best conditions possible to achieve cloud free, snow free, ice free, smoke free, and leaf off captures. The orthophotography covers 36,103 sq km, has a pixel resolution of 16cm and is accurate to 45 centimetres on the ground at 95%. The imagery was acquired by an Vexcel UltraCam X and Vexcel UltraCamEagle digital cameras and was later orthorectified using an elevation dataset generated through image correlation.

Compressed GeoTIFFs: These images are JPEG-compressed GeoTIFFs, and are suitable for analysis in many cases. Should you require uncompressed TIFF files, these may be requested for download by contacting geoportal@scholarsportal.info, and providing your name and institution (ex. University of Guelph).

Please note: Due to the size of these tiles (~500 MB each), please request a portion of the data only. This can be done by including a polygon file of the study area, a description of a desired feature/area (ex. UTM campus), or a screenshot in your e-mail.
How to Cite This: Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources. Digital Raster Acquisition Project Eastern Ontario (DRAPE) 2019 [digital resource: grid]. Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources, (insert date). Retrieved from http://geo.scholarsportal.info/#r/details/_uri@=118578443.
